source: World Bank staff estimates using data from the United Nations Statistics Division's National Accounts Statistics.

name: NY.ADJ.DMIN.CD
label: Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (current US$)
description: Mineral depletion is equal to the product of unit resource rents and the physical quantities of minerals extracted. It refers to bauxite copper iron lead nickel phosphate tin zinc gold and silver.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (current US$) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in Arundhati Kunte and others' "Estimating National Wealth: Methodology and Results" (1998).

name: NY.ADJ.DMIN.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (% of GNI)
description: Mineral depletion is equal to the product of unit resource rents and the physical quantities of minerals extracted. It refers to bauxite copper iron lead nickel phosphate tin zinc gold and silver.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (% of GNI) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in Arundhati Kunte and others' "Estimating National Wealth: Methodology and Results" (1998).

name: NY.ADJ.DNGY.CD
label: Adjusted savings: energy depletion (current US$)
description: Energy depletion is equal to the product of unit resource rents and the physical quantities of energy extracted. It covers crude oil natural gas and coal.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: energy depletion (current US$) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in Arundhati Kunte and others' "Estimating National Wealth: Methodology and Results" (1998).

name: NY.ADJ.DNGY.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted savings: energy depletion (% of GNI)
description: Energy depletion is equal to the product of unit resource rents and the physical quantities of energy extracted. It covers crude oil natural gas and coal.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: energy depletion (% of GNI) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in Arundhati Kunte and others' "Estimating National Wealth: Methodology and Results" (1998).

name: NY.ADJ.DPEM.CD
label: Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (current US$)
description: Particulate emissions damage is calculated as the willingness to pay to avoid mortality attributable to particulate emissions.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (current US$) to you?
source: Kiran D. Pandey and others' "The Human Costs of Air Pollution: New Estimates for Developing Countries" (2006).

name: NY.ADJ.DPEM.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
description: Particulate emissions damage is calculated as the willingness to pay to avoid mortality attributable to particulate emissions.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (% of GNI) to you?
source: Kiran D. Pandey and others' "The Human Costs of Air Pollution: New Estimates for Developing Countries" (2006).

name: NY.ADJ.ICTR.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted savings: gross savings (% of GNI)
description: Gross savings are the difference between gross national income and public and private consumption plus net current transfers.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: gross savings (% of GNI) to you?
source: World Bank national accounts data files.

name: NY.ADJ.NNAT.CD
label: Adjusted savings: net national savings (current US$)
description: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: net national savings (current US$) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates.

name: NY.ADJ.NNAT.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted savings: net national savings (% of GNI)
description: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
question: How important is Adjusted savings: net national savings (% of GNI) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates.

name: NY.ADJ.SVNG.CD
label: Adjusted net savings including particulate emission damage (current US$)
description: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion mineral depletion net forest depletion and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
question: How important is Adjusted net savings including particulate emission damage (current US$) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates. The conceptual underpinnings of the savings measure appear in Hamilton and Clemens' "Genuine Savings Rates in Developing Countries" (1999).

name: NY.ADJ.SVNG.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted net savings including particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
description: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion mineral depletion net forest depletion and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
question: How important is Adjusted net savings including particulate emission damage (% of GNI) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates. The conceptual underpinnings of the savings measure appear in Hamilton and Clemens' "Genuine Savings Rates in Developing Countries" (1999).

name: NY.ADJ.SVNX.CD
label: Adjusted net savings excluding particulate emission damage (current US$)
description: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion mineral depletion net forest depletion and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
question: How important is Adjusted net savings excluding particulate emission damage (current US$) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates. The conceptual underpinnings of the savings measure appear in Hamilton and Clemens' "Genuine Savings Rates in Developing Countries" (1999).

name: NY.ADJ.SVNX.GN.ZS
label: Adjusted net savings excluding particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
description: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion mineral depletion net forest depletion and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
question: How important is Adjusted net savings excluding particulate emission damage (% of GNI) to you?
source: World Bank staff estimates. The conceptual underpinnings of the savings measure appear in Hamilton and Clemens' "Genuine Savings Rates in Developing Countries" (1999).

name: SP.RUR.TOTL
label: Rural population
description: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the difference between total population and urban population.
question: How important is Rural population to you?
source: The data on urban population shares used to estimate rural population come from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects. Total population figures are World Bank estimates.

name: SP.RUR.TOTL.ZG
label: Rural population growth (annual %)
description: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the difference between total population and urban population.
question: How important is Rural population growth (annual %) to you?
source: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.

name: SP.RUR.TOTL.ZS
label: Rural population (% of total population)
description: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the difference between total population and urban population.
question: How important is Rural population (% of total population) to you?
source: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.

name: SP.URB.GROW
label: Urban population growth (annual %)
description: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.
question: How important is Urban population growth (annual %) to you?
source: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.

name: SP.URB.TOTL
label: Urban population
description: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.
question: How important is Urban population to you?
source: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.

name: SP.URB.TOTL.IN.ZS
label: Urban population (% of total)
description: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.
question: How important is Urban population (% of total) to you?
source: United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.

name: CM.FIN.INTL.GD.ZS
label: Financing via international capital markets (gross inflows % of GDP)
description: Financing via international capital markets is the sum of gross bond issuance bank lending and new equity placement. Bond issuance is the notional amount of bond issuance by government public and private sector borrowers in international capital markets. Bank lending is the committed amount of funds raised by government public and private sector borrowers via international syndicated lending. Equity placement is the notional amount of cross-border equity placement.
question: How important is Financing via international capital markets (gross inflows % of GDP) to you?
source: Dealogic and World Bank GDP estimates.

name: CM.MKT.INDX.ZG
label: S&P Global Equity Indices (annual % change)
description: S&P Global Equity Indices measure the U.S. dollar price change in the stock markets covered by the S&P/IFCI and S&P/Frontier BMI country indices.
question: How important is S&P Global Equity Indices (annual % change) to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Global Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data.

name: CM.MKT.LCAP.CD
label: Market capitalization of listed companies (current US$)
description: Market capitalization (also known as market value) is the share price times the number of shares outstanding. Listed domestic companies are the domestically incorporated companies listed on the country's stock exchanges at the end of the year. Listed companies does not include investment companies mutual funds or other collective investment vehicles. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
question: How important is Market capitalization of listed companies (current US$) to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Emerging Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data.

name: CM.MKT.LCAP.GD.ZS
label: Market capitalization of listed companies (% of GDP)
description: Market capitalization (also known as market value) is the share price times the number of shares outstanding. Listed domestic companies are the domestically incorporated companies listed on the country's stock exchanges at the end of the year. Listed companies does not include investment companies mutual funds or other collective investment vehicles.
question: How important is Market capitalization of listed companies (% of GDP) to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Emerging Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: CM.MKT.LDOM.NO
label: Listed domestic companies total
description: Listed domestic companies are the domestically incorporated companies listed on the country's stock exchanges at the end of the year. This indicator does not include investment companies mutual funds or other collective investment vehicles.
question: How important is Listed domestic companies total to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Emerging Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data.

name: CM.MKT.TRAD.CD
label: Stocks traded total value (current US$)
description: Stocks traded refers to the total value of shares traded during the period.
question: How important is Stocks traded total value (current US$) to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Emerging Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data.

name: CM.MKT.TRAD.GD.ZS
label: Stocks traded total value (% of GDP)
description: Stocks traded refers to the total value of shares traded during the period. This indicator complements the market capitalization ratio by showing whether market size is matched by trading.
question: How important is Stocks traded total value (% of GDP) to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Emerging Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: CM.MKT.TRNR
label: Stocks traded turnover ratio (%)
description: Turnover ratio is the total value of shares traded during the period divided by the average market capitalization for the period. Average market capitalization is calculated as the average of the end-of-period values for the current period and the previous period.
question: How important is Stocks traded turnover ratio (%) to you?
source: Standard & Poor's Emerging Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data.

name: FB.AST.NPER.ZS
label: Bank nonperfoming loans to total gross loans (%)
description: Bank nonperforming loans to total gross loans are the value of nonperforming loans divided by the total value of the loan portfolio (including nonperforming loans before the deduction of specific loan-loss provisions). The loan amount recorded as nonperforming should be the gross value of the loan as recorded on the balance sheet not just the amount that is overdue.
question: How important is Bank nonperfoming loans to total gross loans (%) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund Global Financial Stability Report.

name: FB.BNK.CAPA.ZS
label: Bank capital to assets ratio (%)
description: Bank capital to assets is the ratio of bank capital and reserves to total assets. Capital and reserves include funds contributed by owners retained earnings general and special reserves provisions and valuation adjustments. Capital includes tier 1 capital (paid-up shares and common stock) which is a common feature in all countries' banking systems and total regulatory capital which includes several specified types of subordinated debt instruments that need not be repaid if the funds are required to maintain minimum capital levels (these comprise tier 2 and tier 3 capital). Total assets include all nonfinancial and financial assets.
question: How important is Bank capital to assets ratio (%) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund Global Financial Stability Report.

name: FD.RES.LIQU.AS.ZS
label: Bank liquid reserves to bank assets ratio (%)
description: Ratio of bank liquid reserves to bank assets is the ratio of domestic currency holdings and deposits with the monetary authorities to claims on other governments nonfinancial public enterprises the private sector and other banking institutions.
question: How important is Bank liquid reserves to bank assets ratio (%) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.AST.DOMS.CN
label: Net domestic credit (current LCU)
description: Net domestic credit is the sum of net credit to the nonfinancial public sector credit to the private sector and other accounts. Data are in current local currency.
question: How important is Net domestic credit (current LCU) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.AST.GOVT.CN
label: Claims on governments and other public entities (current LCU)
description: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises advances against future credit authorizations and purchases of treasury bills and bonds net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Data are in current local currency.
question: How important is Claims on governments and other public entities (current LCU) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.AST.GOVT.ZG.M2
label: Claims on governments etc. (annual growth as % of M2)
description: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises advances against future credit authorizations and purchases of treasury bills and bonds net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Money and quasi money (M2) comprise the sum of currency outside banks demand deposits other than those of the central government and the time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
question: How important is Claims on governments etc. (annual growth as % of M2) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.AST.NFRG.CN
label: Net foreign assets (current LCU)
description: Net foreign assets are the sum of foreign assets held by monetary authorities and deposit money banks less their foreign liabilities. Data are in current local currency.
question: How important is Net foreign assets (current LCU) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.AST.PRVT.ZG.M2
label: Claims on private sector (annual growth as % of M2)
description: Claims on private sector (IFS line 32d) include gross credit from the financial system to individuals enterprises nonfinancial public entities not included under net domestic credit and financial institutions not included elsewhere. Money and quasi money (M2) comprise the sum of currency outside banks demand deposits other than those of the central government and the time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
question: How important is Claims on private sector (annual growth as % of M2) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.LBL.MONY.CN
label: Money (current LCU)
description: Money is the sum of currency outside banks and demand deposits other than those of central government. This series frequently referred to as M1 is a narrower definition of money than M2. Data are in current local currency.
question: How important is Money (current LCU) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.LBL.MQMY.CN
label: Money and quasi money (M2) (current LCU)
description: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks demand deposits other than those of the central government and the time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition of money supply is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). Data are in current local currency.
question: How important is Money and quasi money (M2) (current LCU) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.LBL.MQMY.GD.ZS
label: Money and quasi money (M2) as % of GDP
description: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks demand deposits other than those of the central government and the time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition of money supply is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS).
question: How important is Money and quasi money (M2) as % of GDP to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: FM.LBL.MQMY.IR.ZS
label: Money and quasi money (M2) to total reserves ratio
description: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks demand deposits other than those of the central government and the time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold special drawing rights reserves of IMF members held by the IMF and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices.
question: How important is Money and quasi money (M2) to total reserves ratio to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.LBL.MQMY.ZG
label: Money and quasi money growth (annual %)
description: Average annual growth rate in money and quasi money. Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks demand deposits other than those of the central government and the time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). The change in the money supply is measured as the difference in end-of-year totals relative to the level of M2 in the preceding year.
question: How important is Money and quasi money growth (annual %) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FM.LBL.QMNY.CN
label: Quasi money (current LCU)
description: Quasi money refers to time savings and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
question: How important is Quasi money (current LCU) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FP.CPI.TOTL
label: Consumer price index (2005 = 100)
description: Consumer price index reflects changes in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
question: How important is Consumer price index (2005 = 100) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FP.CPI.TOTL.ZG
label: Inflation consumer prices (annual %)
description: Inflation as measured by the consumer price index reflects the annual percentage change in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
question: How important is Inflation consumer prices (annual %) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FP.WPI.TOTL
label: Wholesale price index (2005 = 100)
description: Wholesale price index refers to a mix of agricultural and industrial goods at various stages of production and distribution including import duties. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
question: How important is Wholesale price index (2005 = 100) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FR.INR.DPST
label: Deposit interest rate (%)
description: Deposit interest rate is the rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand time or savings deposits.
question: How important is Deposit interest rate (%) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FR.INR.LEND
label: Lending interest rate (%)
description: Lending interest rate is the rate charged by banks on loans to prime customers.
question: How important is Lending interest rate (%) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FR.INR.LNDP
label: Interest rate spread (lending rate minus deposit rate %)
description: Interest rate spread is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to prime customers minus the interest rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand time or savings deposits.
question: How important is Interest rate spread (lending rate minus deposit rate %) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files.

name: FR.INR.RINR
label: Real interest rate (%)
description: Real interest rate is the lending interest rate adjusted for inflation as measured by the GDP deflator.
question: How important is Real interest rate (%) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files using World Bank data on the GDP deflator.

name: FR.INR.RISK
label: Risk premium on lending (prime rate minus treasury bill rate %)
description: Risk premium on lending is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to prime private sector customers minus the "risk free" treasury bill interest rate at which short-term government securities are issued or traded in the market. In some countries this spread may be negative indicating that the market considers its best corporate clients to be lower risk than the government.
question: How important is Risk premium on lending (prime rate minus treasury bill rate %) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics database.

name: FS.AST.DOMS.GD.ZS
label: Domestic credit provided by banking sector (% of GDP)
description: Domestic credit provided by the banking sector includes all credit to various sectors on a gross basis with the exception of credit to the central government which is net. The banking sector includes monetary authorities and deposit money banks as well as other banking institutions where data are available (including institutions that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other banking institutions are savings and mortgage loan institutions and building and loan associations.
question: How important is Domestic credit provided by banking sector (% of GDP) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: FS.AST.PRVT.GD.ZS
label: Domestic credit to private sector (% of GDP)
description: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector such as through loans purchases of nonequity securities and trade credits and other accounts receivable that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises.
question: How important is Domestic credit to private sector (% of GDP) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: FS.LBL.LIQU.GD.ZS
label: Liquid liabilities (M3) as % of GDP
description: Liquid liabilities are also known as broad money or M3. They are the sum of currency and deposits in the central bank (M0) plus transferable deposits and electronic currency (M1) plus time and savings deposits foreign currency transferable deposits certificates of deposit and securities repurchase agreements (M2) plus travelers checks foreign currency time deposits commercial paper and shares of mutual funds or market funds held by residents.
question: How important is Liquid liabilities (M3) as % of GDP to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: FS.LBL.QLIQ.GD.ZS
label: Quasi-liquid liabilities (% of GDP)
description: Quasi-liquid liabilities are the sum of currency and deposits in the central bank (M0) plus time and savings deposits foreign currency transferable deposits certificates of deposit and securities repurchase agreements plus travelers checks foreign currency time deposits commercial paper and shares of mutual funds or market funds held by residents. They equal the M3 money supply less transferable deposits and electronic currency (M1).
question: How important is Quasi-liquid liabilities (% of GDP) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics and data files and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

name: NY.GDP.DEFL.KD.ZG
label: Inflation GDP deflator (annual %)
description: Inflation as measured by the annual growth rate of the GDP implicit deflator shows the rate of price change in the economy as a whole. The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency.
question: How important is Inflation GDP deflator (annual %) to you?
source: World Bank national accounts data and OECD National Accounts data files.

name: NY.GDP.DEFL.ZS
label: GDP deflator (base year varies by country)
description: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
question: How important is GDP deflator (base year varies by country) to you?
source: World Bank national accounts data and OECD National Accounts data files.

name: PA.NUS.ATLS
label: DEC alternative conversion factor (LCU per US$)
description: The DEC alternative conversion factor is the underlying annual exchange rate used for the World Bank Atlas method. As a rule it is the official exchange rate reported in the IMF's International Financial Statistics (line rf). Exceptions arise where further refinements are made by World Bank staff. It is expressed in local currency units per U.S. dollar.
question: How important is DEC alternative conversion factor (LCU per US$) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics supplemented by World Bank staff estimates.

name: PA.NUS.FCRF
label: Official exchange rate (LCU per US$ period average)
description: Official exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by national authorities or to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. It is calculated as an annual average based on monthly averages (local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar).
question: How important is Official exchange rate (LCU per US$ period average) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics.

name: PX.REX.REER
label: Real effective exchange rate index (2005 = 100)
description: Real effective exchange rate is the nominal effective exchange rate (a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies) divided by a price deflator or index of costs.
question: How important is Real effective exchange rate index (2005 = 100) to you?
source: International Monetary Fund International Financial Statistics.

name: SH.DYN.AIDS.FE.ZS
label: Female adults with HIV (% of population ages 15+ with HIV)
description: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Female rate is as a percentage of the total population with HIV.
question: How important is Female adults with HIV (% of population ages 15+ with HIV) to you?
source: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

name: SH.DYN.AIDS.ZS
label: Prevalence of HIV total (% of population ages 15-49)
description: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
question: How important is Prevalence of HIV total (% of population ages 15-49) to you?
source: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

name: SH.DYN.CHLD.FE
label: Mortality rate female child (per 1000 female children age one)
description: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1000.
question: How important is Mortality rate female child (per 1000 female children age one) to you?
source: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health.  See footnotes for a source.

name: SH.DYN.CHLD.MA
label: Mortality rate male child (per 1000 male children age one)
description: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1000.
question: How important is Mortality rate male child (per 1000 male children age one) to you?
source: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health.  See footnotes for a source.

name: SH.DYN.MORT
label: Mortality rate under-5 (per 1000)
description: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five if subject to current age-specific mortality rates.
question: How important is Mortality rate under-5 (per 1000) to you?
source: Level & Trends in Child Mortality. Report 2010. Estimates Developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF WHO World Bank UN DESA UNPD).

name: SH.H2O.SAFE.RU.ZS
label: Improved water source rural (% of rural population with access)
description: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population with reasonable access to an adequate amount of water from an improved source such as a household connection public standpipe borehole protected well or spring and rainwater collection. Unimproved sources include vendors tanker trucks and unprotected wells and springs. Reasonable access is defined as the availability of at least 20 liters a person a day from a source within one kilometer of the dwelling.
question: How important is Improved water source rural (% of rural population with access) to you?
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

name: SH.H2O.SAFE.UR.ZS
label: Improved water source urban (% of urban population with access)
description: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population with reasonable access to an adequate amount of water from an improved source such as a household connection public standpipe borehole protected well or spring and rainwater collection. Unimproved sources include vendors tanker trucks and unprotected wells and springs. Reasonable access is defined as the availability of at least 20 liters a person a day from a source within one kilometer of the dwelling.
question: How important is Improved water source urban (% of urban population with access) to you?
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

name: SH.H2O.SAFE.ZS
label: Improved water source (% of population with access)
description: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population with reasonable access to an adequate amount of water from an improved source such as a household connection public standpipe borehole protected well or spring and rainwater collection. Unimproved sources include vendors tanker trucks and unprotected wells and springs. Reasonable access is defined as the availability of at least 20 liters a person a day from a source within one kilometer of the dwelling.
question: How important is Improved water source (% of population with access) to you?
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

name: SH.HIV.1524.FE.ZS
label: Prevalence of HIV female (% ages 15-24)
description: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.
question: How important is Prevalence of HIV female (% ages 15-24) to you?
source: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

name: SH.HIV.1524.MA.ZS
label: Prevalence of HIV male (% ages 15-24)
description: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.
question: How important is Prevalence of HIV male (% ages 15-24) to you?
source: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

name: SH.IMM.IDPT
label: Immunization DPT (% of children ages 12-23 months)
description: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against diphtheria pertussis (or whooping cough) and tetanus (DPT) after receiving three doses of vaccine.
question: How important is Immunization DPT (% of children ages 12-23 months) to you?
source: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

name: SH.IMM.MEAS
label: Immunization measles (% of children ages 12-23 months)
description: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against measles after receiving one dose of vaccine.
question: How important is Immunization measles (% of children ages 12-23 months) to you?
source: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

name: SH.MED.BEDS.ZS
label: Hospital beds (per 1000 people)
description: Hospital beds include inpatient beds available in public private general and specialized hospitals and rehabilitation centers. In most cases beds for both acute and chronic care are included.
question: How important is Hospital beds (per 1000 people) to you?
source: World Health Organization OECD supplemented by country data.

name: SH.MED.CMHW.P3
label: Community health workers (per 1000 people)
description: Community health workers include various types of community health aides many with country-specific occupational titles such as community health officers community health-education workers family health workers lady health visitors and health extension package workers.
question: How important is Community health workers (per 1000 people) to you?
source: World Health Organization OECD supplemented by country data.

name: SH.MED.NUMW.P3
label: Nurses and midwives (per 1000 people)
description: Nurses and midwives include professional nurses professional midwives auxiliary nurses auxiliary midwives enrolled nurses enrolled midwives and other associated personnel such as dental nurses and primary care nurses.
question: How important is Nurses and midwives (per 1000 people) to you?
source: World Health Organization OECD supplemented by country data.

name: SH.MED.PHYS.ZS
label: Physicians (per 1000 people)
description: Physicians include generalist and specialist medical practitioners.
question: How important is Physicians (per 1000 people) to you?
source: World Health Organization OECD supplemented by country data.

name: SH.MLR.NETS.ZS
label: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets (% of under-5 population)
description: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets refers to the percentage of children under age five who slept under an insecticide-treated bednet to prevent malaria.
question: How important is Use of insecticide-treated bed nets (% of under-5 population) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.MLR.TRET.ZS
label: Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs (% of children under age 5 with fever)
description: Malaria treatment refers to the percentage of children under age five who were ill with fever in the last two weeks and received any appropriate (locally defined) anti-malarial drugs.
question: How important is Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs (% of children under age 5 with fever) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.MMR.RISK
label: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in: rate varies by country)
description: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future taking into account competing causes of death.
question: How important is Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in: rate varies by country) to you?
source: "Maternal Mortality: Estimates Developed by WHO UNICEF UNFPA and the World Bank"

name: SH.PRV.SMOK.FE
label: Smoking prevalence females (% of adults)
description: Prevalence of smoking female is the percentage of women ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco including cigarettes cigars and pipes and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
question: How important is Smoking prevalence females (% of adults) to you?
source: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

name: SH.PRV.SMOK.MA
label: Smoking prevalence males (% of adults)
description: Prevalence of smoking male is the percentage of men ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco including cigarettes cigars and pipes and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
question: How important is Smoking prevalence males (% of adults) to you?
source: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

name: SH.STA.ACSN
label: Improved sanitation facilities (% of population with access)
description: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population with at least adequate access to excreta disposal facilities that can effectively prevent human animal and insect contact with excreta. Improved facilities range from simple but protected pit latrines to flush toilets with a sewerage connection. To be effective facilities must be correctly constructed and properly maintained.
question: How important is Improved sanitation facilities (% of population with access) to you?
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

name: SH.STA.ACSN.RU
label: Improved sanitation facilities rural (% of rural population with access)
description: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population with at least adequate access to excreta disposal facilities that can effectively prevent human animal and insect contact with excreta. Improved facilities range from simple but protected pit latrines to flush toilets with a sewerage connection. To be effective facilities must be correctly constructed and properly maintained.
question: How important is Improved sanitation facilities rural (% of rural population with access) to you?
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

name: SH.STA.ACSN.UR
label: Improved sanitation facilities urban (% of urban population with access)
description: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population with at least adequate access to excreta disposal facilities that can effectively prevent human animal and insect contact with excreta. Improved facilities range from simple but protected pit latrines to flush toilets with a sewerage connection. To be effective facilities must be correctly constructed and properly maintained.
question: How important is Improved sanitation facilities urban (% of urban population with access) to you?
source: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

name: SH.STA.ANVC.ZS
label: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care (%)
description: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care are the percentage of women attended at least once during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.
question: How important is Pregnant women receiving prenatal care (%) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.STA.ARIC.ZS
label: ARI treatment (% of children under 5 taken to a health provider)
description: Children with acute respiratory infection (ARI) who are taken to a health provider refers to the percentage of children under age five with ARI in the last two weeks who were taken to an appropriate health provider including hospital health center dispensary village health worker clinic and private physician.
question: How important is ARI treatment (% of children under 5 taken to a health provider) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.STA.BFED.ZS
label: Exclusive breastfeeding (% of children under 6 months)
description: Exclusive breastfeeding refers to the percentage of children less than six months old who are fed breast milk alone (no other liquids) in the past 24 hours.
question: How important is Exclusive breastfeeding (% of children under 6 months) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.STA.BRTC.ZS
label: Births attended by skilled health staff (% of total)
description: Births attended by skilled health staff are the percentage of deliveries attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision care and advice to women during pregnancy labor and the postpartum period; to conduct deliveries on their own; and to care for newborns.
question: How important is Births attended by skilled health staff (% of total) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.STA.BRTW.ZS
label: Low-birthweight babies (% of births)
description: Low-birthweight babies are newborns weighing less than 2500 grams with the measurement taken within the first hours of life before significant postnatal weight loss has occurred.
question: How important is Low-birthweight babies (% of births) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.STA.MALN.ZS
label: Malnutrition prevalence weight for age (% of children under 5)
description: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
question: How important is Malnutrition prevalence weight for age (% of children under 5) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

name: SH.STA.MMRT
label: Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate per 100000 live births)
description: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die during pregnancy and childbirth per 100000 live births. The data are estimated with a regression model using information on fertility birth attendants and HIV prevalence.
question: How important is Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate per 100000 live births) to you?
source: Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990-2008. Estimates Developed by WHO UNICEF UNFPA and the World Bank.

name: SH.STA.ORCF.ZS
label: Diarrhea treatment (% of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding)
description: Children with diarrhea who received oral rehydration and continued feeding refer to the percentage of children under age five with diarrhea in the two weeks prior to the survey who received either oral rehydration therapy or increased fluids with continued feeding.
question: How important is Diarrhea treatment (% of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding) to you?
source: UNICEF State of the World's Children Childinfo and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SH.STA.OWGH.ZS
label: Prevalence of overweight (% of children under 5)
description: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
question: How important is Prevalence of overweight (% of children under 5) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

name: SH.STA.STNT.ZS
label: Malnutrition prevalence height for age (% of children under 5)
description: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age (stunting) is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
question: How important is Malnutrition prevalence height for age (% of children under 5) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

name: SH.STA.WAST.ZS
label: Prevalence of wasting (% of children under 5)
description: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
question: How important is Prevalence of wasting (% of children under 5) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

name: SH.TBS.CURE.ZS
label: Tuberculosis treatment success rate (% of registered cases)
description: Tuberculosis treatment success rate is the percentage of new registered smear-positive (infectious) cases that were cured or in which a full course of treatment was completed.
question: How important is Tuberculosis treatment success rate (% of registered cases) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

name: SH.TBS.DTEC.ZS
label: Tuberculosis case detection rate (% all forms)
description: Tuberculosis case detection rate (all forms) is the percentage of newly notified tuberculosis cases (including relapses) to estimated incident cases (case detection all forms).
question: How important is Tuberculosis case detection rate (% all forms) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

name: SH.TBS.INCD
label: Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100000 people)
description: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary smear positive and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
question: How important is Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100000 people) to you?
source: World Health Organization Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

name: SH.VST.OUTP
label: Outpatient visits per capita
description: Outpatient visits per capita are the number of visits to health care facilities per capita including repeat visits.
question: How important is Outpatient visits per capita  to you?
source: WHO OECD and supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.EXTR.ZS
label: External resources for health (% of total expenditure on health)
description: External resources for health are funds or services in kind that are provided by entities not part of the country in question. The resources may come from international organizations other countries through bilateral arrangements or foreign nongovernmental organizations. These resources are part of total health expenditure.
question: How important is External resources for health (% of total expenditure on health) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.OOPC.ZS
label: Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of private expenditure on health)
description: Out of pocket expenditure is any direct outlay by households including gratuities and in-kind payments to health practitioners and suppliers of pharmaceuticals therapeutic appliances and other goods and services whose primary intent is to contribute to the restoration or enhancement of the health status of individuals or population groups. It is a part of private health expenditure.
question: How important is Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of private expenditure on health) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.PCAP
label: Health expenditure per capita (current US$)
description: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative) family planning activities nutrition activities and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
question: How important is Health expenditure per capita (current US$) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.PCAP.PP.KD
label: Health expenditure per capita PPP (constant 2005 international $)
description: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative) family planning activities nutrition activities and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in international dollars converted using 2005 purchasing power parity (PPP) rates.
question: How important is Health expenditure per capita PPP (constant 2005 international $) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.PRIV.ZS
label: Health expenditure private (% of GDP)
description: Private health expenditure includes direct household (out-of-pocket) spending private insurance charitable donations and direct service payments by private corporations.
question: How important is Health expenditure private (% of GDP) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.PUBL
label: Health expenditure public (% of total health expenditure)
description: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations) and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds. Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative) family planning activities nutrition activities and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
question: How important is Health expenditure public (% of total health expenditure) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.PUBL.GX.ZS
label: Health expenditure public (% of government expenditure)
description: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations) and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
question: How important is Health expenditure public (% of government expenditure) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.PUBL.ZS
label: Health expenditure public (% of GDP)
description: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations) and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
question: How important is Health expenditure public (% of GDP) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SH.XPD.TOTL.ZS
label: Health expenditure total (% of GDP)
description: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative) family planning activities nutrition activities and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
question: How important is Health expenditure total (% of GDP) to you?
source: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

name: SN.ITK.DEFC.ZS
label: Prevalence of undernourishment (% of population)
description: Population below minimum level of dietary energy consumption (also referred to as prevalence of undernourishment) shows the percentage of the population whose food intake is insufficient to meet dietary energy requirements continuously. Data showing as 2.5 signifies a prevalence of undernourishment below 2.5%.
question: How important is Prevalence of undernourishment (% of population) to you?
source: Food and Agriculture Organization (http://www.fao.org/faostat/foodsecurity/index_en.htm).

name: SN.ITK.DPTH
label: Depth of hunger (kilocalories per person per day)
description: Depth of hunger or the intensity of food deprivation indicates how much food-deprived people fall short of minimum food needs in terms of dietary energy. The food deficit in kilocalories per person per day is measured by comparing the average amount of dietary energy that undernourished people get from the foods they eat with the minimum amount of dietary energy they need to maintain body weight and undertake light activity. The depth of hunger is low when it is less than 200 kilocalories per person per day and high when it is higher than 300 kilocalories per person per day.
question: How important is Depth of hunger (kilocalories per person per day) to you?
source: Food and Agriculture Organization Food Security Statistics (http://www.fao.org/economic/ess/food-security-statistics/en/).

name: SN.ITK.SALT.ZS
label: Consumption of iodized salt (% of households)
description: Consumption of iodized salt refers to the percentage of households that use edible salt fortified with iodine.
question: How important is Consumption of iodized salt (% of households) to you?
source: United Nations Children's Fund State of the World's Children.

name: SN.ITK.VITA.ZS
label: Vitamin A supplementation coverage rate (% of children ages 6-59 months)
description: Vitamin A supplementation refers to the percentage of children ages 6-59 months old who received at least one high-dose vitamin A capsule in the previous six months.
question: How important is Vitamin A supplementation coverage rate (% of children ages 6-59 months) to you?
source: United Nations Children's Fund State of the World's Children.

name: SP.ADO.TFRT
label: Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1000 women ages 15-19)
description: Adolescent fertility rate is the number of births per 1000 women ages 15-19.
question: How important is Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1000 women ages 15-19) to you?
source: United Nations Population Division World Population Prospects.

name: SP.DTH.INFR.ZS
label: Completeness of infant death reporting (% of reported infant deaths to estimated infant deaths)
description: Completeness of infant death reporting is the number of infant deaths reported by national statistics authorities to the United Nations Statistics Division's Demography Yearbook divided by the number of infant deaths estimated by the United Nations Population Division.
question: How important is Completeness of infant death reporting (% of reported infant deaths to estimated infant deaths) to you?
source: The United Nations Statistics Division's Population and Vital Statistics Report and the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: SP.DTH.REPT.ZS
label: Completeness of total death reporting (% of reported total deaths to estimated total deaths)
description: Completeness of total death reporting is the number of total deaths reported by national statistics authorities to the United Nations Statistics Division's Demography Yearbook divided by the number of total deaths estimated by the United Nations Population Division.
question: How important is Completeness of total death reporting (% of reported total deaths to estimated total deaths) to you?
source: The United Nations Statistics Division's Population and Vital Statistics Report and the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: SP.DYN.AMRT.FE
label: Mortality rate adult female (per 1000 female adults)
description: Adult mortality rate is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is the probability of a 15-year-old dying before reaching age 60 if subject to current age-specific mortality rates between those ages.
question: How important is Mortality rate adult female (per 1000 female adults) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm (2) University of California Berkeley and Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research. Human Mortality Database. [ www.mortality.org or  www.humanmortality.de] downloaded on Dec. 10 2009.

name: SP.DYN.AMRT.MA
label: Mortality rate adult male (per 1000 male adults)
description: Adult mortality rate is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is the probability of a 15-year-old dying before reaching age 60 if subject to current age-specific mortality rates between those ages.
question: How important is Mortality rate adult male (per 1000 male adults) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm (2) University of California Berkeley and Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research. Human Mortality Database. [ www.mortality.org or  www.humanmortality.de] downloaded on Dec. 10 2009.

name: SP.DYN.CBRT.IN
label: Birth rate crude (per 1000 people)
description: Crude birth rate indicates the number of live births occurring during the year per 1000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.
question: How important is Birth rate crude (per 1000 people) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables) (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: SP.DYN.CDRT.IN
label: Death rate crude (per 1000 people)
description: Crude death rate indicates the number of deaths occurring during the year per 1000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.
question: How important is Death rate crude (per 1000 people) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables) (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: SP.DYN.CONU.ZS
label: Contraceptive prevalence (% of women ages 15-49)
description: Contraceptive prevalence rate is the percentage of women who are practicing or whose sexual partners are practicing any form of contraception. It is usually measured for married women ages 15-49 only.
question: How important is Contraceptive prevalence (% of women ages 15-49) to you?
source: Household surveys including Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys by UNICEF.

name: SP.DYN.IMRT.IN
label: Mortality rate infant (per 1000 live births)
description: Infant mortality rate is the number of infants dying before reaching one year of age per 1000 live births in a given year.
question: How important is Mortality rate infant (per 1000 live births) to you?
source: Level & Trends in Child Mortality. Report 2010. Estimates Developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF WHO World Bank UN DESA UNPD).

name: SP.DYN.LE00.FE.IN
label: Life expectancy at birth female (years)
description: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
question: How important is Life expectancy at birth female (years) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables) (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: SP.DYN.LE00.IN
label: Life expectancy at birth total (years)
description: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
question: How important is Life expectancy at birth total (years) to you?
source: Derived from male and female life expectancy at birth. Male and female life expectancy source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables) (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: SP.DYN.LE00.MA.IN
label: Life expectancy at birth male (years)
description: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
question: How important is Life expectancy at birth male (years) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables) (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: SP.DYN.TFRT.IN
label: Fertility rate total (births per woman)
description: Total fertility rate represents the number of children that would be born to a woman if she were to live to the end of her childbearing years and bear children in accordance with current age-specific fertility rates.
question: How important is Fertility rate total (births per woman) to you?
source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm. (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database and (6) household surveys conducted by national agencies Macro International and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

name: SP.DYN.TO65.FE.ZS
label: Survival to age 65 female (% of cohort)
description: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65 if subject to current age specific mortality rates.
question: How important is Survival to age 65 female (% of cohort) to you?
source: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

name: SP.DYN.TO65.MA.ZS
label: Survival to age 65 male (% of cohort)
description: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65 if subject to current age specific mortality rates.
question: How important is Survival to age 65 male (% of cohort) to you?
source: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

name: SP.DYN.WFRT
label: Wanted fertility rate (births per woman)
description: Wanted fertility rate is an estimate of what the total fertility rate would be if all unwanted births were avoided.
question: How important is Wanted fertility rate (births per woman) to you?
source: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SP.MTR.1519.ZS
label: Teenage mothers (% of women ages 15-19 who have had children or are currently pregnant)
description: Teenage mothers are the percentage of women ages 15-19 who already have children or are currently pregnant.
question: How important is Teenage mothers (% of women ages 15-19 who have had children or are currently pregnant) to you?
source: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

name: SP.POP.0014.TO.ZS
label: Population ages 0-14 (% of total)
description: Population between the ages 0 to 14 as a percentage of the total population. Population is based on the de facto definition of population.

name: IP.PAT.NRES
label: Patent applications nonresidents
description: Patent applications are worldwide patent applications filed through the Patent Cooperation Treaty procedure or with a national patent office for exclusive rights for an invention--a product or process that provides a new way of doing something or offers a new technical solution to a problem. A patent provides protection for the invention to the owner of the patent for a limited period generally 20 years.
question: How important is Patent applications nonresidents to you?
source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

name: IP.TMK.AGGD
label: Trademark applications aggregate direct
description: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Aggregate direct trademark applications are those filed by applicants without regard to the residency of the applicant. This figure is used when the national office does not provide a breakdown by direct resident and direct nonresident applications.
question: How important is Trademark applications aggregate direct to you?
source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Madrid trademark applications are those received by the national or regional IP office as a result of an international application filed via the WIPO-administered Madrid System.
question: How important is Trademark applications Madrid to you?
source: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) WIPO Patent Report: Statistics on Worldwide Patent Activity. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

name: IQ.WEF.CUST.XQ
label: Burden of customs procedure WEF (1=extremely inefficient to 7=extremely efficient)
description: Burden of Customs Procedure measures business executives' perceptions of their country's efficiency of customs procedures. The rating ranges from 1 to 7 with a higher score indicating greater efficiency. Data are from the World Economic Forum's Executive Opinion Survey conducted for 30 years in collaboration with 150 partner institutes. The 2009 round included more than 13000 respondents from 133 countries. Sampling follows a dual stratification based on company size and the sector of activity. Data are collected online or through in-person interviews. Responses are aggregated using sector-weighted averaging. The data for the latest year are combined with the data for the previous year to create a two-year moving average. Respondents evaluated the efficiency of customs procedures in their country. The lowest score (1) rates the customs procedure as extremely inefficient and the highest score (7) as extremely efficient.
question: How important is Burden of customs procedure WEF (1=extremely inefficient to 7=extremely efficient) to you?
source: World Economic Forum Global Competiveness Report and data files.

name: IQ.WEF.PORT.XQ
label: Quality of port infrastructure WEF (1=extremely underdeveloped to 7=well developed and efficient by international standards)
description: The Quality of Port Infrastructure measures business executives' perception of their country's port facilities. Data are from the World Economic Forum's Executive Opinion Survey conducted for 30 years in collaboration with 150 partner institutes. The 2009 round included more than 13000 respondents from 133 countries. Sampling follows a dual stratification based on company size and the sector of activity. Data are collected online or through in-person interviews. Responses are aggregated using sector-weighted averaging. The data for the latest year are combined with the data for the previous year to create a two-year moving average. Scores range from 1 (port infrastructure considered extremely underdeveloped) to 7 (port infrastructure considered efficient by international standards). Respondents in landlocked countries were asked how accessible are port facilities (1 = extremely inaccessible; 7 = extremely accessible).
question: How important is Quality of port infrastructure WEF (1=extremely underdeveloped to 7=well developed and efficient by international standards) to you?
source: World Economic Forum Global Competiveness Report.
